Award.AwardTitle: Implementation of a Multidimensional Assessment Tool to Explore the Impacts of Pedagogy on Undergraduate Student Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Assessment/Research (91)
Engineering - Materials Science (57)
Building upon recommendations from national initiatives, this project is testing the proposition that carefully mediated feedback from students to instructors on the effectiveness of engineering course design (instructional practices and curricular materials) can lead to substantial improvements in both instructional practice and student performance. It is examining thoroughly the pedagogical practices of 32 engineering graduate student instructors and faculty with various levels of pedagogical knowledge and teaching experience. This examination is being done through the Global Real-time Assessment Tool for Teaching Enhancement (G- RATE). G-RATE is a multidimensional feedback tool that provides pedagogical feedback to instructors about teaching at various points throughout the semester, frames this feedback within the How People Learn (HPL) framework, and engages instructors in self-assessment to identify areas of pedagogical strength and weakness.

During the course of this project, 2,500 undergraduate engineering students are providing quantitative and qualitative feedback to their instructors about their learning experiences throughout the semester, using the G-RATE tool. Two research questions being addressed. (1) Does feedback through G-RATE improve the development of instructor pedagogical expertise? (2) What is the relationship between this feedback and undergraduate student outcomes (e.g., grades) within observed environments? Quantitative data are being collected from students' class deliverables (e.g., lab reports, exam scores, quizzes) as well as components of the G-RATE. Qualitative data are being collected using interviews with engineering instructors and their students.

Designed outcomes of this project are (1) enhanced instructor pedagogical expertise via the implementation of evidence-based teaching assessments in first-year engineering and materials science and engineering courses; (2) improved undergraduate student outcomes from more effective teaching and curriculum choices (utilizing a mixed-methods approach by integrating both qualitative and quantitative data); and (3) a community support network of engineering instructors engaged in open dialogues about teaching and curricular design for undergraduate engineering courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The Global Real-time Assessment Tool for Teaching Enhancement (G-RATE) is a multidimensional tool developed to assess pedagogical instruction in higher education science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) classrooms. Informed from over ten years of research about the "How People Learn" (HPL) framework and effective pedagogy research in engineering classrooms, the on-line G-RATE platform combines direct observations of classroom instruction to create graphical representations of classroom instruction in an effort to improve classroom instruction and student learning.

The online nature of the G-RATE reduces data analysis requirements for stakeholders and offers archived storage of pedagogical profiles for future use. Instructors with no experience or backgrounds in educational psychology or educational assessment can implement the G-RATE seamlessly, thereby reducing their pedagogical training time and increasing their engagement with profiles of their teaching practice. The G-RATE produces a reliable, valid, theoretically-informed instant demonstration of pedagogy for instructors in a space where few such tools exist.

Goals

This project includes both research and technical goals. The overarching research goal is to determine whether implementation of the G-RATE enhances student learning in observed STEM classrooms. The technical goal is to move the tool from a  native platform to a web-based platform, thereby making it easier for on-line data collection and pedagogical profile retrieval and viewing.

To date, the team has collected data in approximately 30 first-year engineering, chemical engineering, forensics, mathematics, chemistry, and interdisciplinary engineering courses. In spring 2015, the online platform was used for the first time with great success among instructors in Purdue University's IMPACT program, an innovative, university-sponsored teaching program emphasizing student-centered teaching and active learning.

Approach

This work is based on Bransford, Brown, and Cocking's (1999) How People Learn (HPL) framework, which has been found to maximize learning in engineering courses. The four HPL dimensions represented in the G-RATE include knowledge-centeredness, learner-centeredness, assessment-centeredness, and community-centeredness.

A quasi-experimental research design has been used to note three conditions- (1) control (no G-RATE intervention), (2) treatment 1 (receipt of G-RATE profiles with no debrief) and (3) treatment 2 (receipt of G-RATE profiles with a debrief) in observed courses. In some cases, the design has been altered to reflect trends in participation across instructors. Qualitative interviews provided additional insight about G-RATE data collection.

Outcomes

Most recently, data from a 30-item student survey, which were developed based on HPL framework and validated by the project with the total of 483 engineering students, provide pedagogical feedback on classroom activities to instructors from their students' perspectives. From these profiles, instructors note the frequency of HPL occurrences during an observation period and of students? self-reported evaluations of their instruction (framed in the HPL framework). With approximately 30 observed sessions to date in a variety of STEM classrooms and with preliminary findings results noting enhanced student learning in treatment courses (i.e., courses where instructors receive formative feedback and debrief about their teaching practices), future uses of the G-RATE are promising.

Broader Impacts

In September 2015, the G-RATE was licensed through Purdue University's Office of Technology Commercialization, becoming the first innovation at the university to receive a copyright license. Dissemination of G-RATE research findings has occurred at conferences and in journals. Members of the team anticipate that other benefits include the following:

-A potential to transform how instructors reflect on their teaching practices 

-A supplemental assessment to current university course evaluations, which are often biased against women and minorities and do not measure instructor quality accurately

-An alternative to traditional teaching evaluations and Promotion and Tenure practices

-A way to differentiate instructional practices in a crowded higher education market, which is growing increasingly competitive

Selected Citations

Zhu, J., Li, Y., Cox, M.F., London, J., Hahn, J., and Ahn, B. (2013). Validation of a Survey for Graduate Teaching Assistants: Translating Theory to Practice. Journal of Engineering Education, 102, 3, 426-443.
